ovdesc.p: The LMM.INSTALL.CONDS table is a collection of parameters used by both the Money Market and Loans/Deposits systems when processing contract records.
The key to this file is a valid COMPANY.CODE.
The table consists of six major groups of conditions, each of which is further subdivided into a number of individual operating conditions. The six principal groups are:-
DAYS BEFORE A STATUS CHANGE. (fields 1 to 8)
These fields are used by the Loans and Deposits module only.
DAYS BEFORE REPORTS. (fields 9 to 11)
These fields are used by the Loans and Deposits module only.
FIDUCIARIES. (fields 22 to 25)
These fields are used by the Money Market system only.
ACCOUNTING CONDITIONS. (fields 26 to 28)
These fields are used by the Loans and Deposits module only.
CATEGORY CODES. (fields 29 to 89)
The majority of these fields are used by the Loans and Deposits module only.
Those used by Money Market are the Profit and Loss Category codes for interest paid and received.
MISCELLANEOUS. (fields 12 to 21 and 90)

These fields define conditions such as the number of days before a contract is written to History after it has matured; what to do if an account debit requires an override during the 'off-line', and various accrual options.

This field specifies the Profit and Loss Category code that is credited/debited when adjusting interest accruals for the previous year on a liability contract where interest has been paid in advance.
When the system adjusts interest on a liability contract then an entry is booked to the Profit and Loss Category code entered in this field for the previous year's adjustment to the accrual.
Adjustment of interest can be caused by reversal of contract.

This field specifies the Profit and Loss Category code that is credited/debited when adjusting interest accruals for the current month on an asset contract where the interest is payable in arrears.
When the system adjusts interest on an Asset contract then an entry is booked to the Profit and Loss Category code entered in this field for this month's adjustment to the accrual.
Adjustment of interest can be caused by events such as back-valued rate or principal change, reversal of contract or use of the adjustment function.

For example, if there is a back-valued interest rate reduction on an Asset contract then, if interest has accrued on this contract in the current month, there must be a debit to this Category code because too much interest has been accrued.

Specifies whether validation will trap possible input errors when a rate is entered on the LD record. The rate is used as a check to help prevent errors through mis-keying the interest or commission amounts. Only applies where the calculation basis is 'S'.

If this field is set to YES or left null the system will verify that the amount entered is within certain tolerance checks. If the amount is within a 1% tolerance it is accepted; over 1% but less than 5% an override will warn the user; if greater than 5% then the amount or rate were mis-keyed and the system will reject the amount (either the amount or check rate should be amended).

Entering NO here will bypass these checks. This option should be used with care as mistakes can get through. It would be used where specific interest payment schedules are pre-defined that could fall foul of the validation.
For interest the INTEREST.BASIS, INTEREST.RATE and TOT.INTEREST.AMT fields apply
For commission COMM.CAL.METHOD, COMM.RATE and TOTAL.COMM.AMOUNT apply.
The user wants to specify an interest amount of USD 100,000 on a12 month loan contract of USD 900,000 so the maturity amount will be exactly USD 1 million. A check rate of 10.95 is entered.
If the interest is entered as USD 10T or USD 10M it would be rejected as it would be outside the 5% tolerance.
USD 101T for this example would be over 1% and would generate an override.
An entry of exactly USD100T would be OK.
Any value entered is accepted

The input at this field instructs the system how to continue processing during the 'off-line' when an entry would require an override.

During the end of day processing the system call to accounting is replaced by a call to EOD ACCOUNTING. This ensures that there is no need for a user to be at the screen when a possible override condition is reached. The important parameter in this call, as far as the user is concerned, is the field EOD ACCT MODE which can have one of the following values:-
A) SAO - (System Automatic Override) - any override condition will automatically have the answer 'YES' assigned to it.

B) SSS - (System Suspense) - any override condition will automatically have the answer 'YES' assigned to it if the entry is to an internal account. An entry to a customer account will be replaced by an entry to a suspense account in the event of an override condition being encountered.
1 - 3 alphabetic characters - the only input allowed is 'SAO'(meaning System Automatic Override) or 'SSS'(meaning System Suspense). (Mandatory input).

Input at this field specifies the frequency with which interest is to be accrued on local currency contracts. The user has the choice of either daily OR monthly accruals and the following examples define the various options:-
(i) 12 DEC 1985 D - this input specifies that the first interest accrual shall be on 12th Dec 1985 and thereafter interest accruals shall be at daily (D) intervals.

(ii) 31 JAN 1985 M0131 - this input specifies that the first interest accrual shall be on 31st Jan 1985 and thereafter interest accruals shall be at monthly (M01) intervals on the last day (31) of each month.
(iii) 31 JAN 1985 M0115 - this input specifies that the first interest accrual shall be on 31st Jan 1985 and thereafter at monthly (01) intervals on the fifteenth day (15) of each month.

Indicates whether interest on contracts based on floating rates, are to be accrued on a daily basis or only when a rate change occurs. This field has an effect only when accruals as specified in fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and ACC CYCLE F CCY are set to "monthly". Setting of fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and ACC CYCLE F CCY to "daily" overrides this field. If fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and ACC CYCLE F CCY are set to "monthly" frequency then, where interest on a contract is based on a floating rate (e.g. Base Rate) the user is allowed the alternative of instructing the system to calculate interest on a daily basis and pass accounting entries accordingly. Alternatively, the system may be instructed to merely inspect the interest rate on a daily basis but carry out an interest accrual only when there has actually been a rate change on a contract. The following example will clarify the significance of each of these alternatives:- Suppose that a contract runs thus:- Value Day Day Day Day Day Mat. Date 1 2 3 4 5 Date 10% 10% 10% 11% 11% 9% 9% A) Input of '1' at this field will instruct the system to carry out the interest accruals on a daily basis and pass accounting entries accordingly. This means that on day 1 the system will calculate interest at 10% on the contract for one day and pass the appropriate accounting entries. Similarly, at day 2 it will again calculate interest at 10% on the contract for one day and pass the accounting entries. At day 3 there is a rate change to 11% and the system will therefore calculate interest on the contract for one day at 11% and pass entries and so on through to maturity of the contract. B) Input of '2' at this field will instruct the system only to carry out interest accruals when there has been an actual rate change. Thus on each of days 1 and 2 the system will merely check the interest rate on the contract, find that the rate rate has remained at 10% throughout, and will not therefore carry out an interest accrual. However, at day 3 the system will check the interest rate, find that it has moved up from 10% to 11% and will then calculate interest on the contract for two days at 10% and pass the appropriate accounting entries. It will then continue to check the rate on a daily basis until it finds that at day 5 the rate fell back from 11% to 9% when it will then accrue interest on the contract for a further two days, but at 11% and again pass the appropriate accounting entries. It will continue with this procedure until contract maturity. Note: If the appropriate accrual cycle field (field ACC CYCLE L CCY or ACC CYCLE F CCY according to currency of the contract) was set to "DAILY" then the difference between method "1" and "2" above would not be apparent since accruals would always be done daily. This field only comes into effect when fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and/or ACC CYCLE F CCY are "MONTHLY".

Indicates whether interest on contracts based on floating rates, are to be accrued on a daily basis or only when a rate change occurs.

This field has an effect only when accruals as specified in fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and ACC CYCLE F CCY are set to "monthly". Setting of fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and ACC CYCLE F CCY to "daily" overrides this field.

If fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and ACC CYCLE F CCY are set to "monthly" frequency then, where interest on a contract is based on a floating rate (e.g. Base Rate) the user is allowed the alternative of instructing the system to calculate interest on a daily basis and pass accounting entries accordingly. Alternatively, the system may be instructed to merely inspect the interest rate on a daily basis but carry out an interest accrual only when there has actually been a rate change on a contract.
The following example will clarify the significance of each of these alternatives:-
Suppose that a contract runs thus:-
Value Day Day Day Day Day Mat. Date 1 2 3 4 5 Date

A) Input of '1' at this field will instruct the system to carry out the interest accruals on a daily basis and pass accounting entries accordingly. This means that on day 1 the system will calculate interest at 10% on the contract for one day and pass the appropriate accounting entries. Similarly, at day 2 it will again calculate interest at 10% on the contract for one day and pass the accounting entries. At day 3 there is a rate change to 11% and the system will therefore calculate interest on the contract for one day at 11% and pass entries and so on through to maturity of the contract.

B) Input of '2' at this field will instruct the system only to carry out interest accruals when there has been an actual rate change. Thus on each of days 1 and 2 the system will merely check the interest rate on the contract, find that the rate rate has remained at 10% throughout, and will not therefore carry out an interest accrual. However, at day 3 the system will check the interest rate, find that it has moved up from 10% to 11% and will then calculate interest on the contract for two days at 10% and pass the appropriate accounting entries. It will then continue to check the rate on a daily basis until it finds that at day 5 the rate fell back from 11% to 9% when it will then accrue interest on the contract for a further two days, but at 11% and again pass the appropriate accounting entries. It will continue with this procedure until contract maturity.

Note: If the appropriate accrual cycle field (field ACC CYCLE L CCY or ACC CYCLE F CCY according to currency of the contract) was set to "DAILY" then the difference between method "1" and "2" above would not be apparent since accruals would always be done daily. This field only comes into effect when fields ACC CYCLE L CCY and/or ACC CYCLE F CCY are "MONTHLY".
1 Numeric character. The only valid input allowed is "1" (meaning book daily irrespective of rate change) or "2" (meaning book only when there is a rate change). (Optional input. Default = "1")
Input must be "1" or "2".
